https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/egi:10R4BR545X7/MAIN/application/pdf/fba4ea61bd16d4a61be1bf78cfcf8560/am.pdf MCAT 113820 113820 S2468-8231(24)00003-8 10.1016/j.mcat.2024.113820 The Authors Fig. 1 SEM images of BFO with various shapes. (a) BFO nanospheres, (b) BFO nanofibers, (c) BFO nanosheets, (d) BFO nanoparticles. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [47–50] with permission. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Outlines the detailed mechanism of BFO piezoelectric catalysis: (a) The original electrostatic equilibrium state of polarized piezoelectric materials. (b) Under compressive stress, the shielding charges are released from the surface and combine with O2 and H2O to generate reactive substances. (c) The corrected static equilibrium state is reached under maximum compressive stress. The figure was reproduced from the reported figure [51] with permission. (d) As the compressive stress decreases, the piezoelectric material absorbs charges from the surrounding electrolyte while reducing the stress. (e) Redox reaction during photocatalytic process. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) The morphology and generation of piezoelectric charges under mechanical vibration of BFO. (b) The band diagram of BFO without and with mechanical vibration. (c) Schematic diagram of heterojunction BiFeO3@TpPa-1-COF with built-in piezoelectric field. (d) The hydrogen production of BFO-BTO nanoparticles under different vibration times and the reaction mechanism of BFO-BTO piezoelectric catalysis for hydrogen production. (e) The piezoelectric catalytic hydrogen production rate of BFO/Pd with different Pd loadings at a frequency of 40 kHz for the first 1 hour. (f) Schematic diagram of the energy band duality of BFO/Pd under ultrasonic vibration and the mechanism of hydrogen production by BFO/Pd. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [72–74,77] with permission. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) The kinetic linear simulation model of the change of the degradation rate of MO dyes with time under visible light irradiation when BFO nanoparticles are polarized for 10 min under different voltages, and the schematic diagram of energy band for BFO nanoparticles before and after polarization treatment. (b) Comparison of RhB degradation rate constants of BFO NS and NW under light, ultrasound, and two combined effects, as well as visual color changes and mechanism diagrams of four different organic dyes under dual stimulation of BFO NWs within 2 h. (c) The degradation kinetics of CBZ under the combined action of sunlight irradiation, ultrasonic vibration, light irradiation ultrasonic vibration within 30 min, and the schematic diagram of piezoelectric enhanced La-BFOs photocatalysis for BFO without doping, 0.05La doping, 0.1La doping, and 0.2La doping. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [79,81,87] with permission. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) The relevant reaction rate constant (k) values for Ag2O@BiFeO3, and the piezoelectric photocatalytic mechanism scheme. (b) The reaction rate constant k of BFO, CFO@BFO under light, ultrasound, and magnetic fields and the piezoelectric photocatalytic mechanism scheme. (c) 50 % BVO/BFO under ultrasonic vibration and visible light for three different organic dye solutions degradation, as well as the synergistic piezoelectric photocatalytic process of BVO/BFO heterojunctions. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [90–92] with permission. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) Schematic diagram of a photocatalyst co loaded with photocatalysts for CO2 reduction and oxidation on semiconductors for solar fuel production. (b) The energy maps of different products of CO2 reduction indicate the required number and charge transfer reaction time scale range for e − and H +. (c) Changes in CO2 production of BFO and BiFeO3- x during 1–9 h of piezoelectric photocatalytic process. (d) The Electronic band structure of BFO and its associated oxidation Reduction potential. (e) Charges migration in response to spontaneous potential with stress variation of the piezo-photocatalysts combining Co-N-C and BiFeO3 (Co-N-C@BFO); Diagrammatic sketch outlining the piezo-photocatalytic mechanism of the Co-N-C@BFO. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [95,96,99,103] with permission. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) The mechanism of BFO piezoelectric catalytic degradation of RhB dye under ultrasound stimulation. (b) Compared with the control plate, the counting images of viable colonies on the agar plate after 24 h of incubation under different conditions. (c) The percentage of mortality and the variation of fluorescence intensity over time. (d-k) The FESEM micrograph of Escherichia coli. (m) The filtration efficiency and disinfection performance of MoS2/PANI/PAN@BiFeO3(PPBM-H) against E. coli and S. aureus. (n) Photocatalytic filtration degradation and charge transfer mechanism explaining by energy band of PPBM-H. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [105,107] with permission. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Schematic diagram of the intracrystalline electron leverage strategy for BiFe0.97Mn0.03O3 nanoparticles reinforced CDT. In vivo CDT performance of MBFO guided by BFO and IEL, schematic diagram of in vivo experiments, body weight of mice, and relative tumor volume maps of different treatments during treatment, Kaplan Meier survival curves of different treatment mice, tumor tissues stained with DHE, TUNEL, and H&E were used for different treatments. (b) Under the alternating magnetic field, the core shell CFO-BFO NPs magnetoelectro-catalytic chemical reaction was initiated to ablate the tumor model, tumor growth curves of all mice after various treatments. In vivo tumor proliferation curves of the mice with 4T1 tumors after undergoing various treatments, and tumor weights of mice after treatments. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [111,113] with permission. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) The schematic diagram of the internal electric field formed by BFO nanomembrane implant. Quantitative analysis of bone implant contact (BIC) values. Different bone volume/total volume (BV/TV) maps based on tissue morphology analysis (* P<0.05, * * P<0.01). (b) Ultrasonic mechanism of BFO/Ti3C2, Blood routine of each group after 2 and 14 days, and H&E staining of bone marrow tissues after 2 days. The red arrows indicate inflammatory cells, ELISA analysis of IL-10 and TNF-α from bone marrow tissues after 2 days and Giemsa staining of bone marrow tissues after 2 and 14 days. The green arrows indicate bacteria. The figures were reproduced from the reported figures [118,120] with permission. Applying mechanical stress to a material with piezoelectric characteristics can generate a piezo-potential, which manifests as a substantial built-in electric field. This piezoelectric built-in electric field has been demonstrated to serve as a potent means for altering the energy of charges or facilitating the movement of both electrons and holes. BiFeO3 (BFO) have garnered significant interest as a class of layered nanomaterials, and is appealing in various applications primarily due to their exceptional properties, such as abundance, photoelectric property, biosafety, photocatalysis and photothermal conversion. Here, a brief review of BFO-based nanomaterials based on recent research progress is provided, mainly covering photocatalytic performance and it in biological area. In this review, we systematically summarized the advances of its surface characteristics, including facet engineering, doping, morphology control, vacancy engineering, facet engineering, heterojunction, and others, which are well-suited for applications in photocatalysis, antibacterial treatments, photodynamic therapy, and other applications. Challenges stem from the complex interactions between BFO-based nanomaterials, light, and biological systems are discussed, such as light absorption range, charge carrier dynamics, ROS generation control, stability, durability, and photocatalytic pathways. This review provides insights into how nanomaterial design, surface engineering, and careful optimization can lead to the development of efficient and biocompatible photocatalysts with broad potential in different fields. Graphical abstract This work systemically introduces BFO-based nanomaterials on their applications in photocatalysis, antibacterial treatments, photodynamic therapy, and other applications basing on the piezoelectric built-in electric field.
