Introduction BiFeO3 (BFO) is a highly researched single-phase multiferroic material known for its ferroelectric and antiferromagnetic properties [1,2]. It exhibits a rhombohedral perovskite structure in single crystal form at room temperature along [110] direction, transitioning from a cubic structure at high temperature (Curie temperature TC ∼1103 K) [3]. The structural inhomogeneity arises from the shifting of Bi3+ ions relative to the Fe-O octahedron [4,5]. The ferroelectricity of BFO stems from the hybridization of the 6s2 lone pair electrons of Bi3+ with either its 6p empty orbit or the O 2p orbit [6–8]. This hybridization results in the distortion of the asymmetric center of the electron cloud. However, pure BFO is challenging to prepare without secondary phases and various defects, making it difficult to accurately measure its true ferroelectric polarization. Epitaxial bismuth ferrite thin films have been successfully fabricated using thin film technology, and their measured ferroelectric polarization approaches the theoretical value [9–11]. BFO exhibits G-type antiferromagnetism (Néel temperature TN ∼643 K), where each Fe3+ ion is surrounded by six Fe3+ ions with parallel spin orientations along its direction [12,13]. In comparison to many other ferroelectric materials, BFO has a narrower band gap (∼2.6 to 2.7 eV) and demonstrates good visible light photocatalytic performance [14]. BFO also display favorable piezoelectric properties, and the piezoelectric value can be tuned when doping with elements such as Fe, Sc, Ga [15]. However, at temperatures above 400 °C, the resistivity of BFO decreases significantly, leading to diminished piezoelectric properties and limiting its high-temperature applications [16]. The piezoelectric effect encompasses both the positive and inverse piezoelectric effects [17]. It describes the exchange of mechanical energy and electrical energy in dielectric materials [18,19]. When a piezoelectric material is mechanically deformed or subjected to an applied stress, it causes a displacement of positive and negative charges within the material. This charge separation creates a polarization electric field and generates a voltage across the material. The magnitude of the generated voltage is directly proportional to the applied stress. Upon removal of the external force, the material returns to its original state [19]. When combined with light-induced charge generation, the piezoelectric built-in electric field can facilitate the separation of the photo-generated charge carriers and enhance their mobility, thereby improving the efficiency of various catalytic reactions [20]. Representative piezoelectric materials can be categorized into nonferroelectric and ferroelectric materials. Nonferroelectric materials, such as quartz and ZnO, exhibit piezoelectric properties due to their crystal structure and symmetry [21]. Ferroelectric materials possess both piezoelectric and ferroelectric properties, barium titanate (BaTiO3) [22], lithium niobate (LiNbO3) [23], potassium sodium niobate (K0.5Na0.5NbO3 or KNN) [24] and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [25] and its copolymers are examples of ferroelectric materials commonly used in piezoelectric applications [26]. BFO is a well-known ferroelectric material for piezoelectric catalysis with strong spontaneous polarization (50 μC/cm2) and high piezoelectric coefficient (d 33≈100 pm/V) [27]. Indeed, the piezoelectric properties of BFO have been found applicable in various fields, including piezoelectric catalysts, piezoelectric antibacterial methods, and piezoelectric anti-cancer treatments [28,29]. In terms of piezoelectric photocatalysts, BFO is a unique material capable of absorbing visible light [30]. The combination of piezoelectricity and photocatalysis in a single material offers several advantages. For example, mechanical stress applied to the material can induce built-in polarization electric field, accelerating the separation and migration of the photogenerated charge carriers [27]. This, in turn, can influence the efficiency and selectivity of the photocatalytic reactions. Thus, when BFO is exposed to light, it first undergoes a process called photoexcitation, where photons (light particles) transfer energy to the electrons. Under the driving of polarization electric field, the excitation promotes some of the electrons and holes separating and migrating directionally, enabling the electron-hole pairs carrying on photo-redox reactions on the surface of the material [31,32]. Moreover, the photoredox progress involves other cooperative reactions including selective organic synthesis, which also utilizes electrons and holes simultaneously [33–39]. This has implications for improving the efficiency of catalytic reactions, including water splitting, organic pollutant degradation, and CO2 reduction processes. It's worth noting that while the concept of piezoelectric photocatalysts is promising, it is still an active area of research, and the development of practical materials with optimized performance and stability is ongoing [40–42]. Researchers are working to discover and design novel materials or modify existing ones to achieve efficient and durable piezoelectric photocatalysts for real-world applications. Furthermore, in the field of biology, piezoelectric antibacterial, piezo-photodynamic therapy has emerged and received intense attention. The field of bio-piezoelectric materials has garnered significant interdisciplinary research attention due to the growing understanding of the influence of piezoelectricity on biological systems. Studies have revealed the potential of piezoelectric materials to affect cellular behavior, tissue regeneration, and biological processes [43]. Research investigations have demonstrated that nanomaterials exhibit antibacterial activities through various mechanisms. These mechanisms include [44]: 1) Deformation and penetration: Nanomaterials with sharp edges can physically interact with bacterial membranes, leading to their deformation and penetration. This disrupts the integrity of the bacterial membrane, resulting in cell death. 2) Electron transport: Nanomaterials can facilitate electron transfer between the material surface and bacteria, interfering with bacterial metabolism. This disruption of electron transport pathways inhibits bacterial growth and survival. 3) Oxidative stress: Nanomaterials can induce oxidative stress in bacteria by generating reactive oxygen species (ROS). These ROS can damage bacterial cellular components, including proteins, lipids, and DNA, leading to cell death. The material substrates in the reports utilize a piezoelectric chemical conversion process to generate ROS in the presence of ambient oxygen (O2) and water (H2O) with ultrasound and illumination [45]. Once the ROS are generated, they can enter bacterial cells through the disturbed bacterial membrane facilitated by the piezoelectric signals. The disruption of the bacterial membrane allows the ROS to penetrate the cell and exert their antibacterial effects. ROS can cause oxidative damage to bacterial cellular components, leading to cell death [45]. Under light irradiation, photosensitizers incorporated with BFO can generate reactive oxygen species to effectively destroy bacteria or eliminate tumor cells, providing a potential solution to biotherapy. The development of BFO piezoelectric material is crucial, particularly in the biomedical field. Materials possessing piezoelectric properties can generate electrical signals within the mechanical environment of the human body [46]. This offers the advantage of avoiding the use of external power sources and implanted electrodes, thereby reducing the risk of side effects such as overheating, pain, and infection. The potential applications of BFO piezoelectric properties in diverse fields highlight the importance of further advancing and exploring its capabilities. Continued research and development in this area hold promise for addressing various challenges and expanding the application scope of BFO. The development and exploration of BFO-based bio-piezoelectric materials offer exciting prospects for advancing biomedical technologies. However, further research is still needed to optimize material properties, understand the underlying mechanisms, and explore new applications in areas such as drug delivery, biosensing, and bioelectronic interfaces. In this comprehensive review, we present a broad perspective on piezo-photocatalysis and bio-piezoelectric platforms based on BFO, focusing on their manufacture and design. We systematically outline the representative structures of BFO and BFO composites, with an emphasis on their manufacturing and design strategies, and their diverse applications in environmental and biomedical fields. It aims to provide valuable insights for researchers and practitioners in these field, promoting further advancements in piezo-photocatalysis and bio-piezoelectric systems and their integration into practical applications. Furthermore, the review discusses the future challenges and opportunities associated with BFO piezoelectric systems in practical applications. By addressing these challenges, researchers can pave the way for the development of more advanced and effective piezoelectric platforms for electrochemistry, sensing, electronics, energy harvesting and therapy. Morphological diversity of bismuth ferrite The preparation method of bismuth ferrite has been very mature, and there are several commonly used methods for synthesizing BFO: 1) Hydrothermal method: The hydrothermal method is a commonly used synthesis method. Bismuth and iron salts (such as bismuth nitrate and iron nitrate) are mixed with an appropriate alkaline solution and subjected to a high-temperature, high-pressure hydrothermal reaction. By adjusting the reaction temperature, reaction time, and alkaline concentration, the morphology and crystal structure of BFO can be controlled. 2) Solid-state reaction: This is a traditional synthesis method, Bi2O3 and Fe2O3 are mixed in appropriate proportions and then calcined at high temperatures. The reaction takes place under suitable atmosphere conditions, such as oxygen or sodium oxide atmosphere, resulting in the formation of BFO. 3)Sol-gel method: The sol-gel method is suitable for preparing nanoscale BFO. In this method, metal salts (such as ammonium bismuthate and iron chloride) are dissolved in a solvent to form a sol, which is then gelated through hydrolysis, condensation, and heat treatment processes to form a BFO gel. Finally, the gel is converted into crystalline BFO through a calcination process. 4) Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD): CVD is a method used to prepare thin films of BFO. In this method, metal organic precursors or metal halides are decomposed in a high-temperature atmosphere, resulting in the deposition of BFO on the substrate surface. This method is commonly used for thin film or multilayer structure fabrication. Thus, the solid phase reaction method, hydrothermal method, sol-gel method, and gas phase deposition method mentioned above are several commonly used methods. These methods can select the appropriate process to synthesize bismuth ferrite according to the need to obtain the desired morphology, crystal structure and size. In addition, the most suitable method can be selected according to the specific experimental conditions and equipment availability. In general, the preparation method of bismuth ferrite has been extensively studied and developed, and has reliability and repeatability. In this review, we mainly focus on BFO synthesized by hydrothermal and sol-gel methods with various shapes. For examples, Fig. 1 a displays BFO cubic-like particles (∼100–500 nm) synthesized by hydrothermal method at 200 °C for 6 h [47]. Each lump of BFO is made up of a lot of little squares held together. The surface of BFO is irregular. A smooth surface in BFO nanofibers can have certain advantages in various applications. For example, in devices or coatings, a smooth surface can provide better contact and adhesion, leading to improved performance and functionality. Fig. 1b shows BFO nanofibers obtained through electrospinning and annealing. BFO nanofibers with smooth surface can be got through electrospinning [48]. When tune the pH value of the solution during the synthetic process, the morphology can be regulated. Fig. 1c is a square shaped structure of BFO with a size of ∼400 nm under pH value of 10–11 by dropping NH3·H2O. The average thickness of BFO nanosheets is about 50 nm [49]. The BFO nanoparticles in Fig. 1d was prepared by a simple coprecipitation method and calcined at 600 °C for 3 h [50]. So, the size, morphology, and arrangement of the constituent particles or structural elements can have profound effects on physical properties and behaviors. For example, in optical applications, the size and morphology of nanoparticles or nanowires can dictate their absorption, emission, or scattering properties. In catalysis process, the surface area and porosity of a material affect its catalytic activity and selectivity. Therefore, understanding and optimizing the synthesis techniques and processes are vital to achieve the desired microstructure and consequently obtain the desired properties of a material. This knowledge enables researchers to develop materials with tailored characteristics for specific applications. The higher visible light photocatalytic activity of BFO correlates with the impact of growth parameters on the physicochemical properties, encompassing particle size, surface state, and phase structure. Understanding the size and morphology-dependent properties is essential for tailoring BFO for specific catalytic, as well as the biological applications. Working principle of piezo-catalysis effect Indeed, piezoelectric materials possess a unique property that allows them to convert mechanical stimuli, such as vibrations, pressure, or stress, into electrical signals (direct piezoelectric effect) or vice versa (inverse piezoelectric effect). This characteristic makes them highly sensitive to mechanical vibrations, enabling them to respond to various mechanical forces. Moreover, the combination of piezoelectricity and catalysis opens up exciting avenues for further research and innovation. This synergy facilitates the development of efficient, self-powered catalytic systems that harness mechanical vibrations to drive specific chemical reactions. The working principle of piezoelectric catalysis can be understood through the following explanation [51] (Fig. 2 ): Fig. 2a likely illustrates a diagram representing a poled piezoelectric material, where the positive and negative charges on the surface are balanced by screening charges [52,53]. This balance of charges ensures that the material remains electrically neutral as a whole. In Fig. 2b, the reduction in the amplitude of polarization in the poled piezoelectric material is likely a consequence of applying compressive stress, which results in negative strain. The piezoelectric effect, as mentioned earlier, generates electric polarization in response to mechanical stress, and in this case, compressive stress causes the polarization to diminish. As the amplitude of polarization decreases, the charge distribution within the poled piezoelectric material changes. The compressive stress-induced reduction in polarization leads to the release of excess screening charges from the surface of the material. These excess charges disperse into the surrounding solution, becoming free charges. The presence of free charges in the solution can induce a progression of chemical reactions, particularly in water. The free charges can interact with H2O molecules, leading to the production of reactive species such as hydroxyl radicals (•OH) and superoxide anion free radical (•O2̄) [54–58]. These reactive species are highly reactive and possess strong oxidizing properties, making them capable of initiating various chemical transformations. In Fig. 2c, when the maximum mechanical stress is applied to the poled piezoelectric material, the bound charges are minimized. The compressive stress at this stage causes a reduction in the amplitude of polarization to a minimum, leading to decreased bound charges on the material's surface. As the excess screening charges continue to release, the material undergoes a process of reaching a new electrostatic balance. This involves the redistribution of charge carriers until a new equilibrium is achieved. At this point, the piezoelectric material stabilizes in a configuration where the forces from compressive stress and electrostatic interactions are in balance, resulting in a new steady-state charge distribution. As the administered force diminishes (i.e., a positive strain relative to the maximum applied stress in Fig. 2c), the polarization in the poled piezoelectric material increases. The material responds to the reduction in mechanical stress by augmenting its polarization, leading to the adsorption of charges from the surrounding electrolyte. The charges with opposite polarity to those adsorbed can participate in oxidation–reduction reactions, generating •OH or •O2̄ reactive species again. When a piezoelectric material undergoes periodic stress, such as mechanical vibrations or deformation, in the presence of an electrolyte, it continuously releases excess charges during each stress cycle. These excess charges lead to the generation of reactive species, such as •OH or •O2̄ in the surrounding electrolyte. The associated redox reactions and potential (pH=0) are shown in Fig. 2e. Researchers are actively integrating piezoelectric materials into photocatalytic systems with the aim of enhancing the overall efficiency and practicality of photocatalysis. This integration holds tremendous promise for diverse applications, such as clean energy generation and environmental remediation. By combining the unique properties of piezoelectric materials with photocatalysis, scientists seek to unlock new avenues for sustainable and impactful technological advancements. Application in environment field Piezo-photocatalysis hydrogen production Photocatalytic overall water splitting, a process that produces H2 and O2 from water using renewable energy without the need for costly and polluting sacrificial agents, is considered an efficient and environmentally friendly approach [59–62]. Researchers are actively working on enhancing the efficiency of overall water splitting by designing heterostructures, ion doping, and controlling the size and the morphology of the materials [63,64]. However, photocatalysts for overall water splitting based on oxides are limited by solar energy utilization efficiency. The effective utilization of catalysts is impeded by the inefficient segregation and movement of photo-generated charges, along with inadequate kinetic overpotentials for redox reactions. To address these challenges and improve the efficiency of overall water splitting, ongoing research focuses on developing novel catalysts and optimizing their properties. Indeed, utilizing piezoelectric built-in electric field as a continuous driving force has demonstrated effectiveness in expediting the parting and conveyance of photo-generated carriers [65–68]. Researchers have explored numerous piezoelectric/ferroelectric nanomaterials for their potential in photocatalysis water splitting, such as ZnO, BFO, BaTiO3, KNbO3, and PZT [69]. These materials hold promise for advancing photocatalytic processes due to their unique piezoelectric properties and their ability to enhance the efficiency of photo-generated charge carrier separation and transfer. However, pure BFO faces a limitation in achieving photocatalytic hydrogen generation due to its conduction band edge being around 0.33 eV, which exhibits a greater positive value than the redox potential of the H2/H2O couple [70,71]. It is delightful that the band bending can solve this puzzle. In the study conducted by You et al.[72], the thin BFO nanosheets bend when subjected to mechanical vibration, this bending leads to the generation of positive and negative charges on the surfaces of the nanosheets. The negative electric charges (q −) generated on the surface of BFO nanosheet attract dissociated hydrogen ions in the water, promoting the production of H2 through the reduction reaction. On the other side of the nanosheets, positive charges (q +) accumulate and are consumed by the sacrificial agents (SO3 2−) during the oxidation reaction (Fig. 3 a). A significant hydrogen production rate of 124.1 μmol/g during 1 hour of mechanical vibration (100 W) stimulation. Additionally, after 50 min of vibration, the decomposition rate of RhB dye reached 94.1 %. It is important to note that the band gap of BFO is about 2.27 eV, and its flat band potential is 0.32 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The introduction of mechanical vibration causes the energy band to bend, making the energy level more negative and reaching the level of producting H2, and the polarization electric field enable carriers on opposite surfaces to produce H2 and the oxidation reaction (Fig. 3b). In summary, the piezoelectric effect in the BFO nanosheets, combined with their suitable band gap, enables efficient charge separation and utilization during photocatalytic hydrogen generation, making them promising candidates for green and sustainable energy applications. On the other hand, creating heterojunctions by coupling semiconductor photocatalysts and piezoelectric material BFO is an innovative approach to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of separation and transfer photo-carriers. A strategy involves SrTiO3-coated BFO nanoparticles was reported [70]. This modification addresses the issue by enabling H2 evolution under visible light. The combined heterostructure better aligns energy levels, promoting more efficient charge carrier separation and utilization. In the study conducted by Xu et al., a Z-type heterostructure piezoelectric photocatalyst called BiFeO3@TpPa-1-COF was developed by combining covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and BFO through covalent bonds (Fig. 3c) [73]. The internal fields can be utilized as driving forces to enhance the overall photocatalytic water decomposition performance. It illustrates that when light and ultrasound are combined, the heterojunctions gain advantages from the cooperative alignment of chemical potential disparities and piezoelectric potential variances. Under illumination and ultrasonic vibrations, electrons migrate from right to left, and holes move in the opposite direction, corresponding to the shift in the polarization direction of the inherent piezoelectric field from left to right. Consequently, the enhancement of the piezoelectric potential in the heterojunctions speeds up the detachment of electron-hole pairs, thereby boosting the photocatalytic redox performance and improving water hydrolysis efficiency. Under the action of this heterostructure, the yields of H2 and O2 were reported to be 1416.4 μmol/g and 708.2 μmol/g, respectively. By coupling semiconductor catalysts with piezoelectric materials to construct heterostructures, the polarization charges from the piezoelectric materials induce the distortion of energy bands at the interface, attracting photogenerated carriers with opposite charges. This enhances the separation of photogenerated carriers for water decomposition. This work holds both theoretical and practical value in utilizing solar and mechanical energy to achieve efficient overall water decomposition. Indeed, the combination of different materials in a solid solution can lead to synergistic effects and beneficial properties that are not achievable with individual components. In the context of piezoelectric catalysis for hydrogen evolution reactions (HER), both BFO and BaTiO3(BTO) have certain limitations that can be addressed by forming a solid solution (BiFeO3-BaTiO3) (Fig. 3d) [74]. BTO exhibits good piezoelectric properties, making it suitable for efficient piezoelectric energy conversion. However, it has a wide band gap of approximately 3.19 eV. On the other hand, BFO has a narrower band gap of around 2.2 eV but with poor piezoelectric properties. Additionally, BFO has a conduction band (CB) that is misaligned with the redox potential of the HER, which limits its effectiveness as a piezocatalyst for hydrogen generation. By combining BFO and BTO to form a solid solution, researchers can tailor their properties to achieve a desirable balance. The solid solution can inherit the good piezoelectric properties from BTO and benefit from the narrower band gap of BFO. The reduction in the band gap is crucial for enhancing the solar energy utilization efficiency, allowing it to absorb a broader range of the solar spectrum. The solid solution can be engineered to have a CB edge position that is tuned close to the redox potential of the HER (≤0 V vs RHE). When the (0.7BiFeO3–0.3BaTiO3) solid solution was subjected to ultrasound vibration, it demonstrated efficient hydrogen production through the HER. The achieved high production rate of 2.72 mmol/g in just 3 h indicates the excellent piezocatalytic performance. 0.7BiFeO3–0.3BaTiO3 also displayed robust piezocatalytic degradation of various types of dyes when subjected to low-frequency mechanical vibration generated by magnetic stirring, showcasing its versatility as a piezocatalyst for various applications. Cocatalysts serve as electron and hole traps at the surface of the photocatalyst [75]. By capturing the photogenerated electrons or holes, cocatalysts prevent their rapid recombination. This method increases the lifetime of charge carriers, making them available for further catalytic reactions [76]. Yang et al. investigated the combination of well-defined BFO (a piezoelectric semiconductor) and Pd (a cocatalyst) to demonstrate the piezocatalytic behavior for hydrogen evolution [77]. The findings showed that Pd, anchored on the surface of BiFeO3 (Fig. 3e), played a dual role in enhancing the piezocatalytic activity for H2 evolution. The presence of Pd on the surface of BFO efficiently extracted the electrons that were generated due to piezoelectric effects in BFO (Fig. 3f). This separation is critical to prevent electron-hole recombination, which would hinder the overall efficiency of the piezocatalytic process. With just 10 mg of the BFO/Pd cocatalyst, an impressive H2 evolution rate of 11.4 μmol h −1was achieved under 100 W vibration excitation at a 40 kHz resonance frequency. This rate was 19.0 times higher than that achieved with pristine BFO alone. The success of the BFO/Pd cocatalyst in achieving such a remarkable improvement in H2 evolution highlights the potential of the cocatalyst engineering approach. By combining suitable cocatalysts with piezoelectric semiconductors, researchers can significantly enhance the efficiency and performance of piezocatalytic processes. Piezo-photocatalysis degradation of pollutants Piezo-photocatalytic materials have a wide range of potential applications, including organic pollutant degradation and water purification [78]. Zhang et al. shows the corona poling process applied to as-prepared BFO nanoparticles to investigate its effects on photocatalytic activity and phase structure [79]. The photocatalytic activity of the BFO nanoparticles is evaluated before and after the corona poling treatment (Fig. 4 a). Under visible light irradiation, the degradation performance of polarized BFO nanoparticles for methyl orange (MO) dye was significantly improved compared to unpolarized BFO nanoparticles. The degradation rate of MO dye was measured by polarizing BFO nanoparticles at different voltages for 10 min under visible light. The results of the study show that the photocatalytic degradation rate of MO (Methyl Orange) dyes was significantly enhanced when using polarized BFO catalysts at 5.75 kV for 10 min. Among the tested conditions, the maximum photocatalytic degradation rate achieved was approximately 70.8 %. The schematic diagram illustrates the energy band changes of BFO nanoparticles before and after corona polarization treatment. The corona polarization treatment of the BFO nanoparticles leads to increased energy band bending. This internal electric field serves as a propelling factor for the efficient parting of photogenerated electrons and holes, diminishing the likelihood of carrier recombination. The corona polarization treatment also affects the concentration distribution of semiconductor carriers and alters the Fermi energy level of the semiconductor material. Thus, these changes influence the chemical reaction performance of the photocatalytic material, further adjusting its photocatalytic activity. Overall, the corona polarization treatment of BFO nanoparticles enhances their photocatalytic performance by improving the separation of electron-hole pairs and reducing carrier recombination, leading to more efficient degradation of organic pollutants under visible light irradiation. In addition, the morphology of nanoparticles has an important effect on the photocatalytic effect. The morphology of nanoparticles can affect their surface area, crystal structure, light absorption and light scattering properties, so as to regulate the photocatalytic performance [80]. In the study conducted by Mushtaq et al., pure single crystal BFO nanosheets (NSs) and nanowires (NWs) were prepared for the degradation of organic pollutants, such as RhB, using visible light and mechanical vibration [81]. when both illumination and mechanical oscillations were simultaneously employed, the BFO nanowires exhibited a remarkable degradation capability, with 97 % of RhB dye being degraded within just 1 hour (k value 0.058 min−1). Fig. 4b illustrates the RhB degradation rate of BFO nanostructures under piezoelectric catalysis compared to photocatalysis. It can be observed that the RhB degradation rate under piezo-photocatalysis is much higher than under photocatalysis, with BFO nanosheets showing a 2.5-fold increase and BFO nanowires showing an 8.5-fold increase. This enhancement is attributed to the piezoelectric effect, which utilizes the internal electrical bias of BFO to regulate the electrical transport characteristics at the BFO-electrolyte heterojunction. This driving force of separation of electron-hole generated during piezoelectric catalysis enhances its photochemical reaction performance. The localized surface charges generated by the piezoelectric effect facilitate the chemical reactions involved in the degradation of dye molecules. Furthermore, the study observed that when the BFO sample was simultaneously excited by both light and ultrasound (US), the piezoelectric photocatalytic reaction rate constant (k = 0.0582 min−1) was higher compared to using light or ultrasound alone. The enhancement provided by piezoelectric photocatalysis was even higher than the linear sum of the individual effects of light and ultrasound, particularly for BFO nanowires. The reaction mechanism in Fig. 4b involves the spontaneous dissociation of water molecules into H + and OH− ions, and highly favorable adsorption of OH− on the BFO surface. However, these electron-hole pairs have a tendency to recombine, restricting the quantity of accessible carriers that can travel to the surface of BFO and commence redox reactions. The polarization built-in electric field of BFO separates the charge carriers and facilitate their migration to the surface, thereby increasing the likelihood of initiating redox reactions during piezocatalysis. These redox reactions involve various reactive species, including e −, h +, •OH and •O2̄. The lattice structure of a catalyst, especially in perovskite materials like BFO, plays a pivotal role in determining its catalytic performance. The compositional diversity of BFO allows for the tuning of its physicochemical properties, making it a versatile material for various applications. Replacing lattice sites with suitable elements or ions is a successful approach for adjusting the multiferroic characteristics of BFO [82,83], which offers a way to tailor its characteristics for specific purposes. When a specific doping agent is introduced through lattice site substitution, several important effects can be achieved: 1) Enlargement of lattice distortion and promotion of polarization: the doping agent can induce lattice distortion in BFO, leading to changes in its crystal structure and unit cell dimensions. This lattice distortion can enhance the piezoelectric and ferroelectric properties of the material, promoting polarization and making it more responsive to mechanical stress or electric fields [84]. 2) Suppression of cycloid spin and room temperature ferromagnetism: BFO exhibits a cycloid spin structure at room temperature [85], which can limit its application in certain contexts. By carefully selecting the doping agent, it is possible to suppress the cycloid spin and induce room temperature ferromagnetism in BFO [86]. This makes the material more suitable for spintronics and magnetic applications. By precisely controlling the doping process, researchers can fine-tune the properties of BFO to meet specific requirements for catalysis. In the research conducted by Lan et al., La-doped BFO achieved a strong magnetic response and high-voltage electro-photocatalytic activity [87]. The degradation kinetics of carbamazepine (CBZ) under the combined action of sunlight irradiation, ultrasonic vibration, and simultaneous light irradiation with ultrasonic vibration were investigated for undoped BFO, 0.05La-doped BFO, 0.1La-doped BFO, and 0.2La-doped BFO samples, as shown in Fig. 4c. Notably, for each sample, the reaction rate constant (k value) of the piezoelectric photocatalytic process was significantly higher than that of individual piezoelectric catalysis and photocatalysis. When sunlight and mechanical vibration were applied simultaneously to La-BFOs dispersed in wastewater, 94.5 % of CBZ was degraded within 30 min through piezoelectric photocatalysis, with a reaction constant 2.2 times higher than the sum of photocatalysis and piezoelectric catalysis. The saturation magnetization value of 6.6 emu/g allows the catalysts to be readily isolated separated from the reaction solution using a magnetic field. In ten consecutive cycling tests, more than 90 % of CBZ, the targeted pharmaceutical contaminant, was successfully removed from the wastewater each time. This finding further indicates that the piezoelectric potential induced by ultrasonic vibration can enhance photocatalytic activity and exhibit a significant synergistic effect. Fig. 4c features a schematic diagram demonstrating that the internal piezoelectric field can adjust the energy band. Through this modulation of the energy band, the curved band structure can raise the CB edge to a more negative level compared to the oxidation–reduction potential of O2/•O2̄, while the VB edge descends to a level defined by the oxidation–reduction potential of •OH/HO• or •OH/H2O. Additionally, the internal electric field provides a driving force that causes photo-generated electrons and holes to transport in opposite directions, diminishing their rate of recombination and expediting their separation. This study not only unveils the promise of magnetic reusable catalysts in water purification to achieve sustainable and cost-effective environments but also showcases the considerable potential of piezoelectric effects in augmenting photocatalytic activity through the synergistic utilization of solar and mechanical energy. To enhance the utilization of visible light and the photocatalytic efficiency of BFO, researchers have concentrated on crafting BFO-based nanocomposites by integrating additional metals or semiconductors to create heterojunctions [88]. These heterojunctions offer several advantages for enhancing photocatalytic performance: 1) Extended light absorption range, 2) Efficient charge separation, 3) Multiple pathways for charge transfer, 4) Synergistic effects [89]. For example, Tran et al. conducted a study on the preparation of a novel piezoelectric photocatalyst by combining p-Ag2O nanoparticles (NPs) with n-BFO nanowires, resulting in the formation of p-n heterojunctions [90]. The researchers compared the performance of this new composite material, Ag2O@BiFeO3, with individual BFO and Ag2O in terms of photocatalytic degradation RhB (Rhodamine B) and tetracycline (TC). The reaction rate constant of the heterogeneous structure showed significant improvements, with the degradation rates of RhB and TC being 570 and 205 times higher, respectively, compared to the individual materials. The Ag2O@BiFeO3 composite exhibited excellent piezoelectric catalytic ability when exposed to visible light and near-infrared with ultrasound irradiation. Within 60 min, the composite material was able to degrade nearly 97 % of RhB, while it achieved nearly 100 % degradation of TC within 120 min. Under near-infrared radiation, the k value of the Ag2O@BiFeO3 composite (20.1 ± 0.59 × 10−3/min) was significantly higher than that of BFO NWs (2.5 ± 0.17 × 10−3/min) and Ag2O NPs (8.8 ± 0.65 × 10−3/min). Furthermore, the application of ultrasound further increased the k value of the composite to 24.8 ± 0.83 × 10−3/min. Fig. 5 a illustrates the piezoelectric photocatalytic mechanism of the Ag2O@BiFeO3 composite material under visible light, near-infrared radiation, and ultrasound. Upon exposed to visible light and near-infrared radiation, Ag2O nanoparticles and BFO nanowires (NWs) produce electron-hole pairs. The photoexcited electrons on the Ag2O NPs diffuse into the CB of the BFO NWs, while the photogenerated holes move from the VB direction of the BFO NWs to the VB direction of the Ag2O NPs until reaching equilibrium at the Fermi energy level. The creation of a p-n heterojunction at the interface facilitates the separation of excited-state electrons and holes between the Ag2O nanoparticles and BFO nanowires, consequently enhancing the photocatalytic efficiency. When ultrasound is applied to the composite material, a piezoelectric potential emerges on the side of the BFO NWs. The negative pressure electric potential close to the p-n interface repels free electrons from the interface, resulting in the enlargement of the depletion zone. The electrons on the CB of the BFO NWs can react with O2 in the solution, yielding superoxide radical anions, while the holes on the valence band of the Ag2O nanoparticles can engage with water molecules, resulting in the generation of hydroxyl radicals. These superoxide radical anions and hydroxyl radicals subsequently play a role in the photocatalytic degradation of contaminants. In conclusion, this composite material holds promise for applications in wastewater treatment and water splitting under diverse environmental conditions. Mushtaq et al. fabricated three types of core-shell nanostructures: CoFe2O4@BiFeO3 (CFO@BFO) Nano Octahedron (NOs), CFO@BFO Nanocubes (NCs), and CFO@BFO NWs [91]. The researchers investigated the degradation of RhB dye using these core-shell structures under the influence of various energy sources. When subjected to individual energy sources (light, ultrasound, or magnetic field), the CFO@BFO NOs exhibited degradation rates of 93 %, 96 %, and 99 % for RhB dye within 1 hour, respectively. Interestingly, when multiple energy sources were applied simultaneously, the degradation rates increased compared to single energy source stimulation. It is shows that the degradation rates of all three core-shell shapes increased when more than one energy source was applied concurrently (Fig. 5b). The increase in piezoelectric photocatalysis activated by dual stimuli can be attributed to the greater availability of energy, leading to an enhanced formation rate of electron-hole pairs. Furthermore, when light and magnetic fields were applied together (light+magnetism), the k value (reaction rate constant) increased compared to when each stimulus was used individually. This enhancement in catalytic efficiency can be ascribed to the synergistic effects arising from the concurrent utilization of distinct energy sources, such as light and ultrasound, or light and magnetic fields. By employing these combined energy methods, the water cleaning performance of the core-shell CFO@BFO photocatalysts was significantly enhanced, resulting in accelerated reaction rates. This study emphasizes that the catalytic efficiency is influenced not only by their shape but also on the stimuli used to activate the catalytic material. In the catalytic reduction scheme, under the influence of light, ultrasound, and magnetic fields, the core-shell CFO@BFO NCs and NWs generate transient charge carriers (electrons and holes). These charge carriers react with oxygen and water to produce •O2̄ and •OH radicals, respectively. The free radicals and holes are responsible for decomposing organic pollutants in the surrounding environment, leading to their degradation into byproducts like H2O and CO2. Jing et al. designed a semiconductor n-p heterojunction between BiVO4 (BVO) and BFO to enhance the piezoelectric photocatalytic process [92]. Under the excitation of piezoelectric vibrations and visible light irradiation, the BVO/BFO heterojunction exhibited a degradation rate of 98 % for a RhB (Rhodamine B) solution within 120 min. The k value of the BVO/BFO heterojunction was found to be 6.12 times that of conventional photocatalysis and 4.36 times that of piezoelectric catalysis. In addition to RhB, the researchers also tested the degradation of MO (Methylene Orange) and MB (Methylene Blue) organic dye solutions via piezoelectric photocatalysis. When the BVO/BFO ratio was 50 %, the piezoelectric photocatalytic degradation rates for RhB, MO, and MB solutions were 98 %, 63 %, and 71 %, respectively. The discrepancies in degradation rates observed among the three dyes can be attributed to distinctions in their molecular structures and underlying catalytic mechanisms. Fig. 5c illustrates the synergistic piezoelectric photocatalytic process of the BVO/BFO heterojunction. The built-in polarization field within the heterojunction facilitates the separation and transfer of charges. Electrons generated by visible light and ultrasonic vibrations easily transfer from p-type BFO to n-type BVO, while holes reverse from n-type BVO to p-type BFO. The built-in polarization field at the interface promotes efficient separation of electrons and holes, maintaining their concentration at a certain level and exhibiting strong redox ability. Additionally, the formation of the built-in polarization field causes the energy band of the n-p type BVO/BFO heterostructure to tilt. This tilting behavior results in the CB edge being more negative than the oxidation–reduction potential of O2/•O2̄ and the VB edge being more positive than the oxidation–reduction potential of OH-/OH. As a result, electrons react with dissolved O2 in water to produce •O2̄, while holes combine with H2O radicals to produce •OH. These highly reactive radicals can attack dye molecules, breaking them down into smaller molecules or even mineralizing them into CO2 and H2O [89]. This distinct construction of the heterojunction not only amplifies the broad-spectrum responsiveness of the catalysts but also efficiently uses mechanical energy from natural sources. The combination of piezoelectric materials with other semiconductors or metals to form heterojunctions offers numerous advantages, making them appealing for a variety of applications, particularly in environmental field. Piezo-photocatalysis reduction of CO2 The research on CO2 reduction reaction (CO2 RR) still presents significant challenges. Photocatalysis has emerged as a promising approach for CO2 reduction, utilizing solar energy to drive the conversion of CO2 into valuable products such as renewable fuels [93]. However, the challenges in photocatalytic CO2 reduction includes the limited energy of the absorbed photons and low carrier separation and transfer efficiency, which can result in relatively low reduction efficiency [94]. It is crucial to make clear of the products and the mechanism during the process of CO2 reduction process. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process used a semiconductor photocatalyst and a CO2-reduction cocatalyst [95]. These photoexcited electrons can then be transferred to the CO2-reduction cocatalyst, which acts as an electron acceptor. Once the photoexcited electrons are transferred to the cocatalyst, they participate in the reduction of CO2 molecules. The reduction reactions result in the formation of various reduction products, such as carbon monoxide (CO, −0.53 eV), formic acid (HCOOH, −0.61 eV), formaldehyde (HCHO, −0.48 eV), methanol (CH3OH, −0.38 eV), and methane (CH4, −0.24 eV). The relative energy level at the heterojunction interface plays a crucial role in determining the efficiency of electron-hole separation and transfer in photocatalytic systems. Fig. 6b presents an energy diagram that depicts the optimal time scale for charge transfer kinetics and the stoichiometric number of electrons (e −) and protons (H +) [96]. It furnishes valuable insights into the dynamics of charge transfer and the coupling of electrons and protons during the photocatalytic CO2 reduction process. Fortunately, piezoelectric catalysis has emerged as a promising approach to tackle some of the challenges mentioned above [49,97]. The efficient separation and transfer of charges by piezoelectric field allows for a higher number of electrons and holes to participate in the reduction of CO2, leading to increased yields of desired products [98]. Xu et al. investigated the synthesis of oxygen vacancy-regulated BiFeO3(BiFeO3 -x ) for the piezoelectric photocatalytic reduction of CO2 [99]. Fig. 6c demonstrates the changes in CO2 production of BFO and BiFeO3- x during 1–9 h of piezoelectric photocatalysis. After 9 h of photocatalytic activity, CO2 was successfully reduced to CO and CH4, with yields as high as 142.6 μmol/g and 32.8 μmol/g, respectively. Furthermore, the mechanical deformation caused by ultrasonic vibration induces displacement of the positive and negative charge centers of the catalyst, forming an internal electric field. Under the influence of the electric field, more charges transfer to the active centers on the surface. This mechanism promotes the photocatalytic reaction process and ultimately improves the efficiency of CO2 reduction. Additionally, the inherent unpaired free charges (excess electrons) generated by oxygen vacancies serve as potential charge carriers in the piezoelectric catalytic process. Introducing oxygen vacancies increases the concentration of free charges, thereby improving the photocatalytic activity. Consequently, the combination of piezoelectric catalysis and photocatalysis exhibits a synergistic effect, mutually enhancing the reduction of CO2. Fig. 6d presents the electronic band structure of BFO and its associated oxidation and reduction potentials. The piezoelectric electric field in piezoelectric catalysis facilitates the transfer and accumulation of electrons and holes on opposite charge surfaces, leading to the tilting of energy bands. This improvement in the energy band level promotes the photocatalytic process. The results highlight the beneficial relationship between piezoelectric and photocatalytic processes, significantly enhancing the efficiency of piezoelectric photocatalytic CO2 reduction. In the piezo-photocatalytic process, it is essential that the catalytic reaction can only occur when the corresponding energy band requirements are met [100]. This means that the energy levels of the material should align with the energy levels required for the desired chemical reaction [101,102]. Some piezoelectric materials may not conform to band requirements, which means they cannot directly participate in the catalytic reactions. However, they can still contribute to the overall process through their piezoelectric properties. In the study reported by Guo et al. (Fig. 6e), BFO was chosen as the piezoelectric material supplier, while Co-N-C (Cobalt-Nitrogen-Carbon) served as the active site for the catalytic reaction [103]. When the duration of ultrasonic and illumination is 5 h, the yields of CO and CH4, which are the reduction products of CO2, reach 1373.41 µmol/g and 169.32 µmol/g, respectively. Co-N-C possesses semiconductor properties, allowing it to directly participate in the CO2 reduction reaction, while the piezoelectric effect induced by the BFO component enhances the charge transfer dynamics and promotes the catalytic process. During mechanical vibration, the continuous production and bursting of bubbles subject the catalyst to periodic stress. According to the principle of displacement current, piezoelectric catalysis prompts BFO to generate displacement current and a time-varying electrostatic potential. This dynamic electrostatic potential drives the piezoelectric effect, leading to an electron flow transferred through the BFO surface to the Co-N-C surface. Moreover, Co-N-C@BFO generates an increased number of photogenerated carriers under light conditions. The displacement current produced by these carriers, through the piezoelectric effect, facilitates the segregation of electron-hole pairs, enabling more electrons to migrate to active sites and actively participate in the CO2 reduction reaction. By combining a piezoelectric material (BFO) with an active site (Co-N-C) with semiconductor properties, the piezo-photocatalytic system achieves efficient charge transfer and CO2 reduction, offering a promising approach for sustainable and energy-efficient catalytic processes. Application in biology Piezo-photocatalysis antibacterial Some researches, inspired by the ROS (•OH, h +, •O2̄ and e −) generation capability of BFO nanoparticles under ultrasonic exposure, aimed to investigate their antibacterial activity [104]. In the study by Roy et al., they reported the synthesis of solvothermal BFO nanoparticles and investigated their piezoelectric activity in the catalytic degradation of the carcinogenic and genotoxic RhB dyes and the pathogenic Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria [105]. The mechanism of piezoelectric catalytic degradation of RhB dye under ultrasound stimulation is shown in Fig. 7 a. The antibacterial activity of BFO nanoparticles combined with ultrasound was evaluated against E. coli over 0, 30, and 60 min. Colony counting was performed to determine the bactericidal effect. Fig. 7b shows the proliferation of bacterial cells over time, with a control group placed under the same conditions for 60 min. When ultrasound was applied without BFO, there was a slight decrease in bacterial growth, but the effect was not significant compared to the presence of BFO. The presence of BFO nanoparticles hindered bacterial growth, as they tended to penetrate bacterial membranes. The estimated mortality rates of ultrasound for BFO at 30 and 60 min in Fig. 7c were approximately 31 %, 66 %, and 94 %, respectively. Within 60 min, the number of colonies formed on the agar plate was almost insignificant, indicating the bactericidal effect of piezoelectric catalysis. The FESEM micrographs in Fig. 7d-k demonstrated the distortion, perforation, and wrinkling of bacterial cells caused by BFO nanostructures and ultrasonic vibration. The antibacterial and bactericidal properties were attributed to the generation of ROS by the piezoelectric catalysis of BFO. The piezoelectric nature of BFO is amplified under mechanical stress, leading to the generation of free radicals ROS (•OH, •O2 −, H2O2). These reactive species have the potential to disrupt transmembrane electron transfer and degrade subcellular components, including DNA, RNA, proteins, and cell membranes. Therefore, the increased production of ROS ultimately impedes cellular functions, leading to cellular damage and, ultimately, cell death. When in a heterojunction system, a material is employed to link two semiconductors, serving as a bridge for facilitating the transfer of photoinduced charge carriers. This innovative design brings about unique properties and functionalities, enabling enhanced photoinduced carrier separation and transfer [106]. For example, MoS2/PANI/PAN@BiFeO3 bilayer hollow nanofibre membrane (PPBM-H) was formed in Fig. 7m-n[108]. The study aimed to investigate the degradation and disinfection performance of the composite material through its photocatalytic filtration and utilization of the piezoelectric effect. Figs. 7m (I)-(II) and (III)-(IV) provide a comparison of E. coli and S. aureus before and after filtration, respectively. The calculated filtration efficiencies for both bacteria are approximately 98 % using a counting method. Under visible-light irradiation, PPBM-H exhibits a remarkable sterilization efficiency of approximately 100 % against E. coli after 60 min. In comparison, PPM only achieves the inactivation of around 3.88 logarithmic units of E. coli within the same time frame. This difference underscores the advantageous characteristics of the bilayer hollow heterojunction system established between BFO and MoS2. Taking advantage of its photo-Fenton and piezoelectric properties, as shown in Figs. 7n, the incorporation of BFO nanoparticles into composite fibers demonstrates remarkable catalytic activity for in situ generated H2O2 from BFO/MoS2. Additionally, these fibers exhibit a pronounced polarization effect under ultrasound radiation, which establishes a built-in electric field to minimize carrier recombination. This system enhances carrier separation, promotes the generation of active radicals, and capitalizes on the tubular structure to expose more amine active sites for interaction with E. coli. Furthermore, the H2O2 produced through the in-situ activation of PPBM-H under visible light irradiation is capable of engaging in a photo-Fenton reaction with BFO. This reaction facilitates the recycling of Fe3+ and Fe2+, effectively addressing the concern of environmental contamination. Under ultrasound, the structural domain of BFO undergoes a transition from different orientations to the same orientation, inducing the piezoelectric effect and polarization. This change results in the appearance of a built-in potential, the generation of a polarized electric field, and the twisting of the semiconductor energy band in BFO. Simultaneously, under visible light excitation, electrons in the conduction band of BFO move towards lower energy levels, while holes in the valence band move to higher energy levels. Consequently, the lower carrier recombination rate allows more electrons and holes to reach the surface of PPBM-H nanofibers, where they combine with O2 and H2O2 in the solution, producing additional reactive radicals for the degradation of TCH. This study thus holds significance for the advancement of other highly efficient self-cleaning multifunctional membranes. It introduces a novel strategy with application value for enhancing photocatalytic performance through the utilization of mechanical energy. Piezo-catalysis for antitumor Cancer dynamic therapy (CDT) is an innovative approach in the field of anticancer strategies. It involves the generation of reactive oxygen species through chemical reactions [108]. In particular, CDT is a notable method, which targets cancer cells by converting endogenous hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) into highly toxic hydroxyl radicals (•OH) through a Fenton catalysis process mediated by Fe2+ ions. This process harnesses the inherent properties of these substances to selectively induce cytotoxicity in cancer cells, offering a promising avenue for combating cancer through ROS-mediated mechanisms [109]. (1) Fe2++H2O2 → Fe3++•OH+OH− (40–80 M−1 s−1) (2) Fe3++H2O2 → Fe2++HO2•+H + (0.001–0.01 M−1 s−1) The efficiency of CDT is fundamentally determined by Eq. (2). From the point of view of reaction kinetics, this is the step that determines the reaction rate due to the high activation energy of Fe3+.This high reaction barrier can reduce the overall reaction rate [110]. Zhao et al. introduced the concept of the "intra-crystalline electron lever (IEL)" strategy to effectively lower the energy barrier of the CDT process [111]. This was achieved by manipulating the local electron density around the Fe reaction center within a perovskite-structured BFO nanocrystal (Fig. 8 a). The synthesis of piezoelectric BiFe0.97Mn0.03O3 nanocrystals was accomplished, where the incorporation of Mn4+-O-Fe3+ bonds played a crucial role. This particular bond configuration exhibited the capability to induce a controlled directional movement of adjacent valence electrons. This phenomenon was achieved through the process of spontaneous local dipole polarization field. In essence, the Mn4+-O-Fe3+ bond arrangement facilitated the redistribution of valence electrons on the Fe site. Furthermore, when subjected to ultrasonic irradiation, the intrinsic electric field present in the modified bismuth ferrite (MBFO) material could facilitate the migration of excess intra-crystalline free electrons. These electrons, originating from the introduction of high-valence Mn4+ as a donor dopant, were directed toward the Fe sites, resulting in a higher accumulation of electrons at these sites. The IEL strategy, which led to an increase in the local electron density on Fe sites, resulted in a remarkable 52.55 % reduction in the activation energy of Fe3+ and a substantial 9.21-fold increase in the yield of •OH. This enhancement in CDT activity was significant. Notably, when assisted by ultrasonic irradiation, this strategy demonstrated highly effective anti-cancer outcomes both in vitro and in vivo, suggesting the potential of the IEL strategy for further advancement in clinical CDT research. To the best of our knowledge, this study represents the first instance where the manipulation of local electron density and atom reactivity has been utilized to enhance Fenton reaction activity and improve CDT efficiency. We firmly believe that this innovative strategy holds immense potential not only in regulating reaction efficiency in fields like electrocatalysis, single-atom catalysis, and biochemistry but also in guiding the future development of on-demand chemical reactivity adjustment. Recent research has ventured into the realm of utilizing a magnetic field as an external stimulus for nanocatalytic tumor therapy [112]. This approach takes the advantages of a noninvasive, highly controllable, and deeply penetrating external stimulus to induce magnetoelectric-responsive production of ROS. This innovative method holds the potential to revolutionize tumor therapy by leveraging the unique properties of magnetic fields and nanocatalysts for enhanced therapeutic outcomes. For example, in the study by Ge et al., they proposed a novel concept of magnetostrictive piezoelectric nanocatalytic drug (MPENCM) for tumor treatment (Fig. 8b)[114].The MPENCM utilizes core-shell magnetostrictive CoFe2O4 and BFO piezoelectric nanoparticles (CFO-BFO NPs) to trigger magnetic driving and piezoelectric catalytic reactions within tumors under alternating magnetic fields. The anticancer activity of CFO-BFO was evaluated using a 4T1 tumor model established on Balb/C mice. Fig. 8b illustrates the process of tumor ablation using the CFO-BFO NPs. The combined treatment group involving CFO-BFO nanoparticles and magnetic stimulation exhibited the most potent tumor growth suppression effect. Remarkably, all tumors in this group were completely eliminated within approximately 5 to 6 days following the initial treatment. In contrast, the control group and other treatment groups showed negligible tumor growth suppression effects. This outcome demonstrates the significant therapeutic potential of the CFO-BFO NPs in conjunction with magnetic stimulation for achieving remarkable tumor eradication results. Obviously, the treated mice via the CFO-BFO nanoparticles combined with magnetic stimulation group, all of them survived for more than 40 days without any recurrence of the tumor. When subjected to an alternating magnetic field, the core-shell nanoparticles initiate a magnetoelectric catalytic chemical reaction. The CFO core generates microscopic stress due to the magnetic confinement effect, producing positive and negative charges on the surface of the BFO shell and creating a strong built-in electric field. This field promotes the generation of two types of ROS, hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radicals, which induce tumor cell death and local solid tumor ablation. This approach sought to determine the impact of magnetic fields on the tumor response to CFO-BFO, shedding light on the potential of this nanomaterial for effective cancer treatment in living organisms. Piezo-catalysis for bone therapeutics Endogenous electric fields are naturally present in living organisms and play significant roles in various biological processes such as development and regeneration. These electric fields are observed to be steady and consistent in vertebrate embryos, particularly in regions where crucial developmental events are taking place [114]. In clinical practice, achieving rapid and effective osseointegration, which is the integration of implants with bone tissue, presents a significant challenge. This process is influenced by the spontaneous emergence of endogenous electronegative potentials at bone defect sites, which play a role in the healing process [115]. Therefore, there is potential to stimulate bone healing by utilizing physiological electric signals within implants. However, directly introducing such physiological electric fields into bone tissue is challenging. Previous studies have shown that external electric fields can induce bone formation. Piezoelectric-responsive biomaterials provide a natural physiological environment to regulate the function of stem cells without the need for foreign drugs or growth factors [116]. The researchers have established built-in electric fields by utilizing electropositive ferroelectric BFO nanofilms in combination with the electronegative bone defect walls [117]. This approach aims to trigger the process of implant osseointegration and facilitate biological healing. For instance, in the study by Wei et al., they utilized the endogenous electronegativity potential at the bone defect site to prepare a positively charged ferroelectric BFO nanomembrane [118]. Fig. 9 a illustrates the schematic diagram of the built-in electric field promoting implant osseointegration. By establishing an internal electric field between the electropositive BFO nanomembrane implant and the endogenous electronegativity bone defect wall, rapid and high-quality osseointegration can be induced on the implant surface. Histological analysis at 2 weeks after implantation confirms good bone integration of the BFO nanomembrane implant, as indicated by the newly formed bone (NB). Quantitative analysis of bone implant contact (BIC) values and different bone volume/total volume (BV/TV) maps based on tissue morphology analysis further support the positive effects of the built-in electric field on osseointegration. When electrical stimulation is applied, conductive polymers activate calcium channels in the cell membrane, promoting the entry of extracellular calcium ions (Ga2+) into the cell and activating the Ga2+ signaling pathway. These changes upregulate the expression of related genes, ultimately promoting osteoblast differentiation. The creating electric fields between the positively charged BFO nanofilm implant surfaces and the negatively charged bone defect walls, which naturally possess endogenous electronegative potential. The built-in electric fields were found to enhance protein adsorption and promote the attachment, spreading, and migration of stem cells, ultimately contributing to the stimulation of bone formation and regeneration. These findings demonstrate the potential of utilizing endogenous electric fields and positively charged ferroelectric nanomembranes, such as BFO, for promoting implant bone integration and enhancing bone repair and regeneration. On the other hand, it is demonstrated that by combining BFO with other materials, it is possible to establish an interfacial charge transfer channel. This is achieved by creating a combination of ferroelectric polarization and a Schottky junction [119]. Such a configuration facilitates and accelerates the transfer of charges at the interface, leading to enhanced electronic interactions and potentially improved performance in various applications. In the study by Li et al., they proposed a strategy to accelerate charge transfer at the interface by combining negatively charged 2D MXene (Ti3C2) and positively charged BFO through electrostatic interactions to form a ferroelectric polarization and Schottky junction [120]. The implosion of the former results in local sono-thermal effects and sonoluminescence. Sonoluminescence refers to the phenomenon where small flashes of light are emitted from the collapsing bubbles. In this process, the intense pressure and temperature created during bubble collapse can trigger the material to produce photogenerated electrons and holes through electron transition. This generation of electron-hole pairs can contribute to various photochemical reactions and processes, potentially leading to unique and useful applications in fields like photocatalysis, energy conversion, and more. Simultaneously, the latter leads to the creation of a piezoelectric field at the interface, which acts as a driving force that facilitates the transfer of photogenerated charges across the interface. This efficient transfer of charges across the interface contributes to the effective separation of holes and electrons, which is crucial for various photoinduced processes and reactions. The combination of these two effects, the sonoluminescence-triggered photogenerated charges and the piezoelectrically induced charge transfer, can lead to enhanced material performance and novel applications in the field of materials science and technology. Fig. 9b illustrates the process where ultrasonic vibration drives the BFO/Ti3C2 composite to generate hole ion bubbles and ferroelectric polarization. The study also conducted blood routine tests to assess postoperative infection levels at 2 and 14 days. Compared to normal blood, the control group (Ctrl) and BFO/ Ti3C2 groups showed higher levels of white blood cells (WBC), lymphocytes (LYM), monocytes (MONO), and granulocytes (GRAN), indicating a stronger inflammatory reaction and severe bacterial infection in the body. Histological analysis using H&E staining showed a large number of inflammatory cells in the Ctrl and BFO/Ti3C2 groups, while the BFO/Ti3C2-US group exhibited only a few inflammatory cells, indicating that BFO/Ti3C2 under ultrasound significantly reduces osteomyelitis and possesses anti-inflammatory properties. Furthermore, the study evaluated the anti-inflammatory ability through ELISA levels. Compared to the Ctrl and BFO/Ti3C2 groups, the BFO/Ti3C2-US group had higher expression levels of IL-10 (interleukin-10) and lower expression levels of TNF-α (tumor necrosis factor-alpha), indicating a weaker inflammatory response. This suggests that BFO/Ti3C2 under ultrasound effectively kills bacteria and alleviates the inflammatory response. Giemsa staining results on days 2 and 14 demonstrated that the Ctrl and BFO/Ti3C2 groups had many bacteria in the bone marrow, indicating severe bacterial infections. In contrast, the BFO/Ti3C2-US group showed only a small number of bacteria on the second day, and even no significant bacteria were found after 14 days, indicating good antibacterial effects. Moreover, the BFO/Ti3C2-US group maintained these indicators within the normal range. Ferroelectric interface engineering provides more driving force and surfaces with unbalanced charge states, allowing more electric charges under ultrasound to participate in the production of reactive oxygen species. This leads to the quick and effective eradication of osteomyelitis caused by bacteria within 20 min. This strategy demonstrates the potential for piezoelectric materials to become effective acoustic sensitizers for bacterial-specific acoustic dynamic therapy. The synergistic effect of ferroelectric polarization and Schottky junction presented in this study provides a new approach for the effective treatment of deep tissue infections, such as osteomyel. Conclusions and outlook In this review article, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent advances in piezo-photocatalysis and bio-application of BFO, highlighting its characteristics and influencing factors. Piezo-based catalysis is an emerging catalytic technique that utilizes mechanical energy to trigger catalytic reactions. This innovative approach has shown great potential in various fields, including environmental purification, water splitting, CO2 reduction, sterilization, and anti-tumor. Multiferroic materials BFO have demonstrated remarkable potential in environmental remediation, yet there are certain unresolved challenges that warrant further investigation. Future studies in the following aspects are expected to advance the development of the piezo-catalytic technique of BFO: 1) Optimizing piezoelectric characterization: Future research should focus on identifying and developing piezoelectric material BFO with enhanced properties, such as higher piezoelectric coefficients. The intrinsic piezoelectric properties should be improved. This can be achieved through defect engineering or doping with specific elements that enhance their piezoelectric response. 2) Mechanical stress optimization: Acoustic cavitation generates high impact forces, reaching levels as high as 105–106 Pa. These forces can exert significant pressure on catalyst materials, potentially leading to wear and degradation. In contrast to the high-impact forces of acoustic cavitation, natural energy sources such as wind and water flow generate relatively low-impact and low-frequency energy. This gentle energy profile is more favorable for the longevity and stability of catalyst materials. Understanding the relationship between the applied mechanical stress and catalytic activity is essential. Further studies should investigate the optimal conditions for mechanical stimulation, including stress amplitude, frequency, and duration. Moreover, improving the sensitivity of piezoelectric materials to mild mechanical forces is crucial for their practical applications. 3) Synergistic effects: Exploring synergistic effects with other external stimuli, such as magnetic fields. Future research could focus on BFO responding to magnetic field stimuli, further improving the catalytic efficiency. 4) Environmental compatibility: The environmental impact of piezocatalytic materials should be assessed comprehensively. Studies on the long-term stability, potential toxicity, and recyclability of piezoelectric material BFO will ensure their safe and sustainable use for environmental remediation. 5) Scale-up and practical application: While piezocatalysis has shown promise in laboratory settings, its practical application on a larger scale requires further attention. Researchers should explore scalable manufacturing methods for piezoelectric catalyst BFO and study its performance under real-world conditions. 6) Theoretical modeling and simulation: Advanced computational techniques can provide valuable insights into the behavior of piezocatalytic systems. More theoretical modeling and simulation studies on the piezo-electric characteristics and energy band analysis, can guide experimental efforts, predict outcomes, and optimize the design of piezoelectric catalysts. 7) Catalyst stability: Ensuring the stability of piezoelectric and piezo-photocatalysts is essential to maintain their performance over extended periods. Researchers need to design BFO-based materials that are resistant to degradation caused by harsh environmental conditions, chemical reactions, and wear from mechanical forces. By addressing these aspects and further advancing the understanding of piezoelectric material properties, researchers can contribute to the development of highly sensitive and practical BFO-based piezoelectric materials with a wide range of applications, including energy harvesting, sensors, actuators, and environmental monitoring. coredata.dc:description: Applying mechanical stress to a material with piezoelectric characteristics can generate a piezo-potential, which manifests as a substantial built-in electric field. This piezoelectric built-in electric field has been demonstrated to serve as a potent means for altering the energy of charges or facilitating the movement of both electrons and holes. BiFeO3 (BFO) have garnered significant interest as a class of layered nanomaterials, and is appealing in various applications primarily due to their exceptional properties, such as abundance, photoelectric property, biosafety, photocatalysis and photothermal conversion. Here, a brief review of BFO-based nanomaterials based on recent research progress is provided, mainly covering photocatalytic performance and it in biological area. In this review, we systematically summarized the advances of its surface characteristics, including facet engineering, doping, morphology control, vacancy engineering, facet engineering, heterojunction, and others, which are well-suited for applications in photocatalysis, antibacterial treatments, photodynamic therapy, and other applications. Challenges stem from the complex interactions between BFO-based nanomaterials, light, and biological systems are discussed, such as light absorption range, charge carrier dynamics, ROS generation control, stability, durability, and photocatalytic pathways. This review provides insights into how nanomaterial design, surface engineering, and careful optimization can lead to the development of efficient and biocompatible photocatalysts with broad potential in different fields.
